Polonnaruwa offers a captivating snapshot of medieval Sri Lankan civilization. The area boasts a dense concentration of ancient ruins, the centerpiece of which is the magnificent Vatadage, a circular relic house spanning 18 meters in diameter. This structure features breathtaking sculptural detail, including four beautifully preserved stone Buddha statues. Another key highlight is the Gal Viharaya, a rock temple renowned for its four antique Buddha statues meticulously carved into a large granite cliff face, each depicted in a unique posture. Visitors should observe a modest dress code when exploring these sacred sites: knees and shoulders must be covered. Given the humid climate, it is wise for those wearing shorts to pack a sarong to don before entering temple grounds. Additionally, be prepared to remove your shoes before entering the temple sites.

Polonnaruwa is an absolute gem for history enthusiasts and anyone fascinated by ancient civilizations. As a UNESCO World Heritage site, it offers a remarkable journey back to the 10th and 11th centuries when this city was the thriving capital of Sri Lanka. The ruins here are incredibly well-preserved, allowing visitors to truly imagine the grandeur of the ancient kingdom. The intricately carved statues, stupas, and temples scattered across the site are breathtaking. Highlights include the Gal Vihara, with its stunning Buddha statues carved out of solid rock, and the Royal Palace, which gives a sense of the architectural splendor of the time. What I found particularly captivating was the sense of tranquility that envelops the entire area. Despite being a popular tourist destination, Polonnaruwa never feels overcrowded, allowing you to explore the ruins at your own pace. Cycling around the site is a popular option and adds a bit of adventure to the experience. Make sure to visit the Archaeological Museum before heading out to the ruins. It provides valuable context and enriches your understanding of the site. Overall, Polonnaruwa is a must-visit for anyone traveling to Sri Lanka. It offers a perfect blend of history, culture, and natural beauty, making it an unforgettable experience. Don‚Äôt forget to carry water, a hat, and sunscreen, as the sun can be quite intense, especially during the midday hours.

Polonnaruwa is a captivating journey into Sri Lanka‚Äôs ancient past, and guiding visitors through this remarkable UNESCO World Heritage site is always a rewarding experience. As a tour guide, I‚Äôm continually impressed by the grandeur and historical significance of Polonnaruwa, which stands as a testament to the island's rich cultural heritage. The city‚Äôs well-preserved ruins offer a fascinating glimpse into the medieval era of Sri Lankan history. From the majestic Royal Palace to the intricate carvings of the Gal Vihara, every corner of Polonnaruwa tells a story of a once-thriving capital. The architectural beauty and scale of these ancient structures are nothing short of awe-inspiring. One of the highlights for many visitors is the chance to explore the Parakrama Samudra, an extensive irrigation system built by King Parakramabahu I. The sheer scale and ingenuity of this ancient engineering feat provide a fascinating insight into the advanced technology of the time. Walking through the ancient streets of Polonnaruwa, I love sharing the historical context and legends that bring the site to life. The blend of ancient temples, royal palaces, and elaborate stone carvings creates a rich tapestry of Sri Lankan history and artistry. For anyone interested in exploring Sri Lanka‚Äôs cultural heritage, Polonnaruwa is an absolute must-visit. Its historical significance, architectural marvels, and serene setting make it a memorable experience for all. Join us on a tour and immerse yourself in the fascinating history and beauty of this ancient city.

The vast archaeological site corresponds to what has been unearthed so far in Sri Lanka's second capital at the end of 900 AD. These numerous and often well-preserved remains are UNESCO World Heritage Sites. The ticket office is across the street from the entrance to the site. There are numerous exhibits but it is not very eye-catching and sometimes the meaning of the exhibition is not even clear. Museum and the 5 focal points of the archaeological site are quite far away, considering the hot weather. A guide with tuktuk costs about 5000 rupees (negotiable) but it's worth it! We, being 4, were able to follow it with our mopeds. Last but not least, the admission price is absolutely disproportionate; $30 per person, without discounts for students, seniors, families, only for children. That said, if you have to choose to neglect a site between Polonnaruwa, Sigirya and Danbulla, skip Polonnaruwa.

My wife and I spent a long half day morning doing the following: Firstly we purchased the Polonnaruwa Ancient Site entry tickets at the Archaeological Museum in Polonnaruwa. The address is WXRX+PFG in Polonnaruwa It cost US$25pp. They take credit card or cash is accepted. There is a ticket office for locals and separate ticket office for tourists which is a bit further down the path on the right. Tourists can also buy online at the official website of sigiriyafortress. The entry ticket is for 3 areas, and as you visit each area they tear off a stub for each one as you enter that particular part. Near the ticket office is where local guides canvass the tourists. Unfortunately we got ripped off and paid too much. The going rate is US$20. The guide jumps in your car with you to move from one site to another. At the end he gets a tuk tuk back home. The guide that hooked us claimed to be an archaeologist who had worked on these ruins. He separated us from our private driver so he could puff up a guiding fee from the usual US$20 to US35. We later found out he was going to share the extra money he conned off us with our driver but our driver told him to just charge us the usual US$20 fee instead. Seems our driver had been duped also. We then went to the Statue of Parakramabahu I (Pothgul Vehera statue) which is located on Bund Road to the north of Polonnaruwa, on eastern bank of Parakrama Samudraa reservoir. This has: - Vatadage Polonnaruwa which is a circular relic house and well preserved - Nissanka Latha Mandapaya that is a pillared structure that is open on all sides - Gal Potha stone inscription is a Stone Book  that is lose between the eastern outer wall of Hetadage and Sathmahal Prasada. Note that for some of these ruins you are required to remove shoes but it well sign posted. Next we went to Gal Vihara aka Uttararama which is impressive with various Buddha‚Äôs carved in a stone wall made of giant granite. One is a reclining Buddha carved into the side of a rock face. The entry fee is included in the Polonnaruwa Ancient Site entry tickets. Visitors need to cover knees and shoulders and has guards checking this. Next we went to Lankathilaka Image House which is a big standing 17meter high Buddha. Second last was Thivanka Image House that is located on Thivanka Pilimage Road in Nissankamallapura. The fee is included in Polonnaruwa entry ticket. Lastly we went to the Lotus Pond (Polonnaruwa Nelum pokuna) that is located 400 metres south of Thivanka Image House. There is a lot more ruins in all these areas but we tried to see the highlights that intersted us.

The ruins are spread over several areas and we were glad we had a private driver/tour guide to show up the way.    This is one of the areas where an audio tour would have been helpful for tourists to understand the significance of each section as the signage on the ruins did not match up with the map/key provided at the first call in the Museum/office. Be aware the Monkeys on these sites are well use to Travelers and are very bold.  If you stop to take a photo of them they will quickly congregate around you
Museum and ruins well worth the visit. undiscovered for 700 years. The Kings Palace with a huge slice off  rock on which 4000 rules are engraved, truly amazing

Brought ticket at museum entrance to visit the ruins. Do the museum first because once you‚Äôve done the ruins, they keep your ticket so you cant pass to anyone else, and you then cant get into the museum later. We cycled through the ruins and it was a really great way to see them. There are places within the ruins to buy cold drinks and snacks and sit for a while. Also shoulders and legs need to be covered in certain areas so dress modestly or carry a shawl

We visited here with a party of seven tourists. We had a guide with us who was knowledgeable and clearly a great help. Some great sites to see but only enhanced by local knowledge and understanding. It will take you all day to see most of the sites so plan accordingly.

Another UNESCO World Heritage Site that worth a visit especially for history buff. An interesting history where the kingdom was built during Chola Dynasty since invasion from South India to the capital city of Anuradhapura, then Polonnaruwa since 10th century. It is said to be a systematic destruction of Buddhism civilisation from the north in Anuradhapura and built Shiva Temple with Hinduism influence. Polonnaruwa was then established with various significant architecture including more superior water irrigation system that flourished agriculture and trade. Both metropolises were then destroyed and burnt after the war and invasion by Kalinga Magha  (founder of Jaffna Kingdom) in 13th century. There are many remnants of the ruins with intriguing stone carvings. Some of the checklist for places to visit at this site include the below: a. Thivanka Image House** b. Polonnaruwa Nelum Pokuna - Lotus** c. Gal Vihara (Rock Temple)** Kiri Vihara - 91** Lankatilaha Viraya - 90** d. Alahana Pirivena - 73** Rankot Vihara** Pabalu Vehera - 52** Sheva Devale - 2-54** e. Hetadage f. Nissankalata Mandapa - 43** g. Vatadage - 39** h. Dalada Maluva - Polonnaruwa** i. Hindu Temple God Shiva Devalaya** j. Palace of King Nishshanka Malla** k. Deepa Uyana l. Palace of King Parakramabahu** j. Council of Chamber** k. Pothgul Viharaya Well worth the steep entrance fee of USD25 and take your time to enjoy the site at your own pace with half to full day tour. Hiring a driver is essential when visiting this site. We used ‚ÄúBLUE HAVEN TOURS‚Äù with an excellent driver Mr Sugath. Drinking water  is essential too.
Came here on our bikes which I think is the best way to visit the site. Loved the ru√Ønes and the history
Spent a good part of a day walking round the ruins of temples and other buildings. Quite crowded, and by time we had finished I felt that I didn‚Äôt want to see another temple!

This is a huge, huge site. We had a private bus tour and we used it to move between the sites, otherwise I don;t know how we would have done it. All the sites are amazing, take at least half a day to see them.
The ruins were easy to access for all ages, it is a worthwhile area to visit. The only downside was the actual museum, there was insufficient information about some or the artifacts.

Lots to see in this ancient and well preserved city which is rightly a UNESCO world heritage site. Shamefully, we spent less than two hours here when at least three would've given us the opportunity to see even more. The Buddhas at Gal Vihara are an magnificent site and we were lucky enough to witness a Religious ceremony during our visit. The Rankot Vihara dagoba was extremely impressive and is still used by pilgrims to leave offerings, most of which were snaffled up by the ubiquitous and fast moving monkeys! Thoroughly recommended.

I visited Polonnaruwa on the way from Negombo to Sigriya. It requires atleast 2-3 hours and is worth the visit. Entrance fee for SAARC citizens (includes India) is USD 12.5 and  you need to produce the passport at the counter. At the museam office they handout a one page guide / map with major attractions, you can go from one place to another in car and visit as many as interest you. Reading the reviews of the key places to visit and keeping a note of them before arriving there is helpful, so as not to waste time there figuring out what to see. There are quite a few to choose from. Given the pleasant weather and the lovely greenery it was more than just visiting some historical place with ruins, the greenery added to the pleasant vibes and overall it was a wonderful experience.

A visit to Polonnaruwa is definitely worth while.  Our tour guide arranged a local guide who took us to the main sites, giving us information about what we were seeing and the history behind it. An amazing place and definitely worth a visit.

We were due to be taken to Sigiriya by our tour guide, but it wasn't really suitable for my post op knee, so he suggested going to the Polonnaruwa archaeological sites... It was a great experience. He drove us between each site and left us to explore the archaeology. It was a really amazing place to explore with each site having old ruined temples which are still considered holy places  and hence no shoes and respectful clothing.. We really enjoyed our time there although it would have been better for us to have gone earlier in the day, as we had to give up on the last temple because it was too hot with our shoes off !... We could see on many of the sites conservation work was going on which was very good , these important historical sites need to be preserved. We saw many people touring on bikes which looked fun and some people were using Tuk-Tuks to travel between the sites... If you like ancient archaeology I highly recommend this place to you.

A must do day out whilst in this region. Really interesting and awe inspiring. Few things to try to do. Visit the museum first which will make the whole place more understandable. If you want to book a guide it is worthwhile but if you struggle with hearing it may be better not to as they don‚Äôt all speak good English. Take a scarf for the sights require ladies to cover legs and shoulders. Wear shoes you can slip on or off as you need to remove them to go up close. There is a number of pedlars at every site. Unless you want to buy anything just say No Thank You. You can go round by car or hire a bike depending on your fitness and heat tolerance level. The toilets for foreigners are very clean and good. Take some small change to tip the attendants. A worthwhile and enjoyable day and leaves you in wonder and awe on how it must of look when in its full glory.

So many tours I looked at went to Anuradhapura but not Polonnaruwa.  I've seen the Save A Prayer video by Duran Duran so I knew I had to see both sites!  Joking aside, Polonnaruwa has so much to offer with its magnificent statues and beautiful stone carvings.  It was definitely worth having on my itinerary.
So far in our trip, this is the premier historical site. I can't image being in Sri Lanka and not visiting here.

Polonnawura richly deserves its status as a World Heritage Site. It can be visited over the course of a day. While a ruin, there are enough tantalizing remains to interest any traveler. The area ruled Sri Lanka from the 11th through 13th centuries. Several buildings here likely held the Tooth Relic. There are other unique structures like the circular Vatadage and the oddly shaped Satmahal Prasada, the purpose of the latter unclear. Places like the Lankatilaka Vihara, stretching to the heavens, will catch any photographer's eye. The sublime sculptures at Gal Vihara represent the best of Sinhalese craftsmanship, the artistry of the Kumara Pokuna, the royal baths, not far behind. It is a more impressive site overall than Anuradhapura.

While much older, the ancient city of Anuradhapura seemed cleaner. Both offer great stupas and statues. At Anuradhapura, be sure not only to take socks, but to wear them, that is unless you are accustomed to walking on very hot surfaces in your bare feet. Shoes must be removed at the entrance to temple and stupa grounds, and much barefoot walking is required. Both ancient cities have their attractions. You are already in Sri Lanka. See them both. Don't cheap out. Anuradhapura took us a out 6 hours, with a driver. Polonnaruwa about 3  hours. The monkeys at Polonnaruwa were really interesting as was the vegetation.

Fabulous historical site. The remaining ruins are of a medieval kingdom that flourished for a short period in the 11-12th centuries. Many amazing bits of architecture The site is huge so if you are not up for a 12 km walk take a Tuk Tuk or rent a bike.  Bike rental is 400 rupees. We walked it and spent the day there.  Enjoyed the archeology and the wildlife. Saw monkey deer and an amazing range of birds including woolly necked stalks and hornbills

Our guide took us to the small museum first, to put everything in context.  It was useful.  Then we hired bikes (ropey and old but functional!) and went into the Polonnaruwa complex.  It spreads over a quite a large area so is well worth hiring the bikes in order to see everything.  I lost count of the amount of buildings - quite a lot of temples still intact and not just ruins.  Everything is labelled in English too, so you can get some background information at each individual site.  It took us a good 3 hours to go round the whole site on bikes - there are various vendors around the site selling snacks, drinks and souvenirs.  The whole experience was very pleasant and a relatively easy ride with only a few slight inclines.  It was interesting to find out more about the ancient civilisations and learn about the culture. A good trip

We visited the site with our guide for the necessary explanation of historic events that led to the build of what now are ruins. Some quite well preserved, but even the less preserved are worth the visit anyway. We biked which made it even more attractive, because it offers the opportunity to experience a larger part of the site when walking and more intens than by car.
very nice and old city but the syst√©m of tickets and entrance is terrible and crazy.. no marks and signs ticket office is almost 2 km far away from entrance.

The site is on a big area and is recommended to have a tuk tuk driver or to rent a bike in order to explore the whole area. Very interesting ruins and I am positively impressed how everything is well maintained and clean, which is a sign that the money of the ticket goes into the preservation, as it should. The museum is also well made and contains some artifacts found on the site. Definitely worth a visit!

I don't want to come across as too much of a Philistine because we came to see the ruins and they were very interesting, our guide gave a nice explanation and Gal Viharaya was particularly impressive in its scale and preservation. It must be said though, the monkeys stole my attention for all but GV, they were everywhere and I could have watched them fighting and playing all day. Apologies to our guide Dan because he probably got fed up of me looking at the monkeys instead of what he was pointing at.

Polonnaruwa covers a huge  area so it is handy having a car that can drive you from one archaeological ruin to another. There are many ruins to explore and learn about. Well maintained areas. Handy to have a guide to explain things but it is not essential. There are many areas to see that are not so popular with tourists so are less crowded so need to make sure you have enough time to explore it all.

It has a lot of beauties about ancient but its very different from the other ancients. I visited for a 2 hour,so i had to skip some points but i think it deserves 3 hours if you want to catch to everypoint
Vast area  with museum and archeological sites. It really is worth spending the 20USD on a guide for 2 hours to get the most out of it.
Polonnaruwa is a must on any visit of the country. The amazing statues of Lord Buddha, rock carvings and ancient moments are all simply beautiful!

It is not a large area and the ruins aren‚Äôt as intact as in Angkor Wat, if a comparison needs to be made. But it is a good introduction to the history of Sri Lanka. The second most ancient of Sri Lanka's kingdoms, Polonnaruwa was first established by the Chola dynasty after their successful invasion of the country's then capital, Anuradhapura, in the 10th century. The Ancient City of Polonnaruwa has been declared a World Heritage Site. Polonnaruwa is the second largest city in North Central Province, but it is known as one of the cleanest and more beautiful cities in the country. Polonnaruwa was ruled by the Kings Vijayabahu I, Parakramabahu the Great and Nissanka Malla ‚Äì all 3 of these rulers devoted themselves to fostering agriculture, religion and social development and the kingdom prospered under their reign during this era.

From the museum to the many sites throughout the ancient city, Polonnaruwa was probably our favourite stop in the Cultural Triangle. Not as old as Anuradhapura, or as well preserved, it is better organized and you can more easily develop an understanding of the different eras and constructions. You‚Äôll need a few hours to see it all, but you‚Äôll want to spend time checking out the different sections and appreciate the artistry evident in many of the ruins. The only drawback are the numerous, persistent vendors at nearly every stop (something that isn‚Äôt condoned at Anuradhapura), but be firm, polite and keep moving and they will leave you be (eventually).
Such a good glimpse back in time. Well worth the trip. Unfortunately we only had half a day, as  the site is so big could easily spend the day here roaming around. Was a great experience.

The only place in Sri Lanka which unveils the history of ancient Sri Lanka. Come here with your friends and family and explore this place. It will at least need one full day from morning to evening. Make sure to come early morning. Tickets to the museum are half the price for indians with Indian Passport and costs LKR2800 approx. Take a guide with you and rent a bicycle to explore the place in the best possible way - its fast and convenient and you get the proper facts and information from your guide. If you are solo, this is the best option as I too did the same. You can also ask your guide to click pictures for you, when you are solo. Check out my full review on my Youtube Channel - Mumbai Musafir.

The size and scale of these ancient ruins is immense. Suggest you use a guide for the background history and significance of this site. If you start at the museum, the archeological sites you‚Äôll visit will follow the path taken through the museum. There is still a lot of work to do to uncover much of what is buried. It took us a whole morning to visit. Beware the monkeys - they are not shy in attempting to take your icy pole! The palace precinct is separate to the temple precinct and yes temple protocol is expected.

We visited the historic ruins of the polonnaruwa  and were not disappointed.  Although it rained throughout the day we managed to see the ruins of the former kingdom and very old Buddhist and hindu temple ruins. This area was the 2nd kingdom in Sri Lanka thousands of years ago and the ruins were discovered by the British. There is also a museum which is worth visiting.  There is an entry fee to see the ruins and its more expensive for tourists but worth it.  Allow to spend at least half a day to see everything.  A lot of the structures is still in very good condition. A must see to appreciate the rich history of Sri Lanka

There were unseasonably heavy rains the day we visited this site.  We recommend visiting the museum first, to get a good overview, and then the ruins.  The history and ruins were fascinating.  We enjoyed it despite walking through ankle deep water at a few points!  We went with a local guide organized by our driver and he had great information and spoke very good English.  We may have enjoyed biking the area had the weather been a bit better!

We stumbled upon this ancient city almost by mistake. It is one of the best preserved ancient cities I have visited and I have been to a few including Pompei and Herculaneum! It is a huge layout and will need the best part of the day to visit but it is well worth it. Make sure you wear a hat as it is hot. The building and the sculptures are well preserved. The city was founded in the 10th century by thee invading Cholas but was kept as capital for future dynasties as well. The Royal Palace, the Swimming Pool, the various Veharas particularly the Gal Vihara is magnificent!

Great to learn about the various aspects of ancient history in Sri lanka. You can bike, walk, drive a car or hire a tuk tuk. Make sure to cover up though as it is roasting out there!! I‚Äôm told by my Sri Lankan in laws that this part of Sri Lanka rarely sees rain hence the intense heat. For me the heat started to take away from it a bit cause It was so intense but I did still enjoy the historic side of it and cycling!! Cool to see but definitely recommend to go earlier in the day before heat rises too much! Recommend. Three stars only because of the heat and humidity (which I know can‚Äôt be helped).

An all-in-one stop to understand the history of early Sri Lanka. Buddhist, Sinhalese, Tamil, Hindu buildings that housed local kings and queens, their people and all that accompanied them. Sophisticated irrigation and water systems, palaces, council chambers, bathhouses and places of worship and learning. Helps to understand the traditions and cultures that shaped the country. If you‚Äôre a pale skinned visitor wear hat, sunscreen and consider long sleeves.
This place was really cool. I loved the history and the amazing experience. Definitely worth checking out if you are in the area

I think the vibes here are a tad nicer than Anuradhapura's, but if you have time of cos go for both :) The place is not too crowded but very hot. Most places you need to remove your shoes, so try to not go when it is scorching ... :D

We really enjoyed this archeological site and spent a good few hours here. Its very impressive. It‚Äôs in the jungle‚Äî there are lots of monkeys, so don‚Äôt bring food inside. We hired a motorcycle from Sigiriya, from Wew Thawulla Restaurant, and saw all the sites via motorcycle. Because the site is very big, some people hire a bicycle to see the place. You can also go by tuk tuk. Some drivers will try to get you to pay all fees to them, instead of the paying the park entrance fee, but know that if you do this, the money does not go towards the park for restorations, so please make the right decision and pay the entrance fee to help the conservation and maintenance for this beautiful site. You can park at the entrances, but when you enter each area, you must take off your shoes‚Äîyou will be taking them off a lot. From Sigiriya, it‚Äôs a one hour drive. Costs $30 to enter site. Ticket office is not at the entrance, it‚Äôs around the corner.

The ancient town of Polinnaruwa is quiet big and u need to take car or bicycle (also hard ) - the distance between the monuments are big and need time . There are very interesting and different . At some of them it‚Äôs not allow for photos . Any how is good experience and history of Sri Lanka . If u don‚Äôt have much time u can skip the museum on the cashier place and go direct to the park . Park is full with friendly monkeys.

For sure you need to go with a guide as the place is so spread out, we had a driver for the entire thing and it was definitely worth it. There are some information boards but not a lot and as some places are temples you need to take your shoes off and cover up. We went when it was raining heavily but it was still amazing to see the ruins

Polonnaruwa was the thriving commercial and religious centre of Sri Lanka some 800 years ago. It consists of a lot of temples and religious buildings. It is UNECSO world heritage site. Before we went into the ruins of the Ancient City, we visited the Archaeological Museum (next to the ticket office). I am recommending this museum for all of tourists, after that no need for a tourist guide in to the Ancient City ( you will recognize all main buildings and tourist sites from the photos and stories in the museum). You can walk, rent a bike or go by car depends of your time and interesting. The enter ticket price is 25$/person and you can pay with US dollars. The best time to visit Polonnaruwa is in the morning, to avoid high temperatures and hot weather. The opening time is 7am-6:30pm daily. We spent more then 4 hours there and we really had a nice time. Go and enjoy on this amazing place!

This is an extensive world heritage classified archaeological site with a large range of very impressive ruins over a wide and carefully tended area, including ancient sunken gardens with sophisticated irrigation systems, and many remains of temples, palaces, monasteries, stupas, tombs and fortifications.  This must have been a truly glorious place in ancient times.

This is a must see UNESCO world heritage site. Well worth the price of admission, and you could spend several hours here. Fascinating history and impressive architecture for the times.  We had a car to shuttle us between locations, but the distances are not too great for walking, or rent a bicycle outside if it's not raining (it was on our visit). We STRONGLY recommend spending 30-60 minutes at the museum where you purchase tickets to the architectural ruins. If you do this, you do not need a private guide when you are walking through the ruins, because you will recognize the main sites and there are brief placard descriptions (including in English) at the main entrance to each site.

You could easily spend hours upon hours here.  There is so much to see and walk around.  We travelled by car, however, you could easily get around walking. The sites are very well preserved for such ancient buildings.  The details are still there and in some places you can still see the white faces that would have covered the buildings. It was a pleasure to go around with my guide and work out what everything was and try to imagine how everything would have looked in the past. Definitely needs to be done and in great detail while here Remember to take your shoes and hats off during all the visits to the temples, as well as covering shoulders and knees! They get very angry if you do not.

This archaeological site is extensive: impressive ruins, remnants of ramparts, sunken gardens, remains of temples, the Royal palace and Council Chambers, stupas, impressive tombs of varying size, a monastic hospital  site, and many steps. The site covers 35ha. and is the largest monastery complex in Polonnaruwa. Parts of the Lankatilaka Vihara still stand; two 17m high walls, each 4m thickness and adorned with impressive murals, form an aisle to a headless 14m high Buddha statue in this ancient temple. We had the services of a terrific guide, he had an encyclopedic knowledge of each structure and ruin and made our visit a rich and rewarding experience.

These ancient structures are so intricately made and so well preserved. For many years, nature has reclaimed the structures in Polonnaruwa. Today, only less than 40% of the old structures and artifacts have been unearthed. We started at the museum to get a glimpse of what we can see inside. You can rent a bike to go around. I personally would not do it because it can get too hot and there is a lot of grounds to cover. Wear cool, comfortable clothes and footwear. For the footwear, aside from comfortable, wear thise that are easy to remove because you will need to remove it to enter some of the sites. There are many animals around just walking and monding their own business - monkeys, monitor lizzards, squirrels and more. The highlight in terms of wildlife was seeing a huge herd of deers eating grass on our way to the big stupa.

I spent near on 6hrs wondering around this ancient temple city & enjoyed, no I loved every minute of it. I found it small enough to be able to walk, an opportunity to get some exercise in, and so was able to follow paths to areas that no one else considered. Most people had drivers or tuk tuks and pretty much stayed on the beaten track. The site was also quite serene & tranquil & had that air of ‚Äòsacredness‚Äô. Thankfully there weren‚Äôt a whole lot of tourists about. Polonnaruwa is apparently the best preserved & I felt rewarded & by the end felt happy enough to have paid the exorbitantly high entry fee. After touring around this site & reading forums I decided to cancel Anuradhapura, again another extremely high entry fee & a site not as well preserved. Doing both would be an overkill. I highly recommend.

I and My wife didn‚Äôt expect our Polonnaruwa trip to be this awesome. We visited a lot of places before we returned to our hotel. From the Palace of King and Shiva Devale to our favorite Stone Book, everything was memorable. I would love to come back again!

Our guide took us here as part of a cultural triangle tour - medieval capital of Sri lanka - wonderful history going back 1000 years and very well presented - the history is quite superb and whilst it is quite spread (so allow plenty of time) it is well worth a long visit - ignore traders who approach you - as others have said not too busy
Polonnaruwa was enlisted 1972 in UNESCO! It was the capital of Sri Lanka from 1059-1207, it was the golden era of the time under two kings ruling! N it was most prosperity time!

This is all about 9th and 10th century ruins in this incredible place. It is on the edge of lake and there are many different ruins and NO tourists. Unlike other cities with similar ruins overrun by tourist buses from Asia, there were none here. The place was almost deserted and we cycled through the many different ruins. Just spend some time here absorbing what an amazing place this would have been many centuries ago.

I cant do hundreds of stairs so this location was easy for me to access walk around. There are many different designs and it was very interesting to see them. Make sure you have someone with you like a guide who can explain it all to you. Just be firm snd say no to anyone who offers you help because the men at the bottom of the stairs know who to target. Prob one of my fav locations on the trip.

This is one of the ancient capitals of Sri Lanka, centuries old and with a number of sites contained therein. Entry is USD 25 for foreigners and USD 12.5 for children (half rate for nationals of SAARC countries). Payment can be made in USD or LKR, but change is returned in LKR only. Paying in USD is every so slightly cheaper when you do the reverse forex rate calculations. Upon paying the entry fee, you can enter the area and see all the various attractions. There is not a lot of information available on-site, so hiring a guide can be worthwhile. There is a museum in the building where you buy tickets, entry to which is complimentary with the Polonnaruwa tickets. However if running short of time, can skip this (which is what we did). Since there are around 26 sites within the premises (all spread apart), it can easily take upwards of 1 whole day to see the place in its entirety and enjoy its beauty. If running short of time, you need to plan in advance and shortlist the places you want to see and first finish those (and then, time permitting see as much of the rest as possible). The Golden Quadrangle, Palace Complex and Gul Vihara are some of the places that i would recommend as must-see. Suggest carrying a lot of water, wearing hats and covering knees. As with most historic ruins, children and people without a sense of history will find this dull, so i would suggest they opt out (instead of paying 25 USD and then realising that they didnt appreciate the beauty of the ruins).

An amazing site! There is no way i can do it justice here! Highly recommended for anyone who likes their history or architecture. Definitely get a guide, we had the former direct of archeology and the tour and the information he gave we‚Äôre fantastic!

A very impressive ancient capital, definitely worth a visit.If you are in the hot season, try to avoid getting there as early as you can, because the hit was almost unbearable. Plus, since it's a sacred site, you are needed to take off you're shoes and hat so in the pick hours of the hit it can even be dangerous. I also recommend to go there with a guide, if you can. It will add to your experience.
A special Historical base in srilanka,  i mostly visit with tourists to this place and they happy with that trips . If some want to study sri lakan's  history and culture, please visit!

My girlfriend and Me paid 25$ each to see some ruines without any good explanations/pictures, who are informative and interactive. We are not specialist and it was complicated for us to visualize places and to understand the history. For an excessive price, it is a shame. I recommend you to walk around the site and the city and looked around ruine, it is same. With a ticket, you will only gets closer but without entertainment.
There are many beautifull place to visit, the site is quite big and you can get lost and miss places. It can easily visited with a tuk tuk, a car is not a must.
Plonnaruwa is full of ancient ruins that will make you fascinated.So many places to explore including wildlife.

Multiple locations in close proximity to visit where one can get a sound understanding of SriLankan history and the culture. Can cover the whole area in about 4hrs. The trees around give good covering from the sun. The Gal Viharaya, Kings Palace are some of the key places to visit are fully worthwhile to see. Can recommend our guide who was very knowledgeable and speaks very good English as well by name of Mr. Premasiri who can be contacted on 0775064817. He was very patient in explaining to my kids aged 9 and 14 We spent 5-6 hours including lunch time enroute to Pasikudah. There are many clean eating places also in close proximity to the cultural sites.

We arranged for our driver to take us to Polonnaruwa. We were going to hire bikes but as it was a scorching hot day, we opted for our driver to drop us at the key sites along the way.. perhaps a little lazy but we did get to see a lot. Drivers are allowed into the site, but not to act as guides without paying extra I think. The site is huge and amazing! Definitely a highlight.

A nice place to visit, there are various different bits to see that are dotted over the site. We visited them all by car with our guide, there is the option to do it by bike but we decided against this in the heat! We saw all the main sites in a morning. Be sure to wear trousers, cover your shoulders and take off your shoes at some of the ruins. There were a lot of people trying to sell you things at certain areas.

We were pleased we hired bikes - from Polo at the Cafeteria in the museum car park - to explore this interesting site. A relatively quick trip around the museum allowed us to orientate ourselves as well as get an idea how the site originally looked before we set off  along the main road before taking the turn into the site itself. We immediately headed north and enjoyed the less crowded Gal Vihara - awe inspiring- and Monastery area before joining the crowds at the Quadrangle and Royal Palace group. The latter was rather disappointing- we had previously strolled around the (free entry) Island Park group of ruins near the museum and found them to be more informative and certainly more comfortable. Allow 3-4 hours - on bikes - to explore the main site and be prepared to observe standard temple visit practices - remove shoes, hats and cover shoulders and knees - at multiple stages of the visit. Water very welcome although there are multiple vendors en route. We visited in August - Sri Lankan school holidays and ahead of the apparently imminent rainy season - so many parts of the site were crowded. An early start might be wise.

There is a tonne on ancient ruins along this stretch! It seems to never end! We had a guide and vehicle where we stopped and then moved further on. If you like history this is well worth a visit, our guide was very informative and it adds to the ruins to understand what was what!

I would not hesitate to name Polonnaruwa as one of the best 10 cities to visit in Sri Lanka. I would also say that it is immaterial whether you are a local tourist or an international tourist. I must also say that, over the years the city is becoming increasingly tourist friendly. About 10 years ago when I used visit here there was hardly any decent restaurant or a place to stay. In a few years time I would expect a marvelous city here. This is beside the old glory of Polonnaruwa that was always a great tourist attraction. The pick of the sites is Gal Vihara inside the historic city that you can enter by purchasing passes. The majestic Buddha statue in Gal Vihara is an overriding reason for me to visit the place again and again. There are many other monuments inside the historic city that a tourist should not miss. Apart from the historic city one should make it a point to visit the Parakrama Samudra (sea of Parakrama) - a sizeable reservoir built by the king Parakramabahu and later expanded by the first Prime Minister of Sri Lanka, D S Senanayake. It's possible to take a boat ride (no motor boats) in the lake which is highly recommended for the birders and bird photographers. There are a few islands in the lake that are are inhabited by many species of water birds. The bank of the reservoir is a great place to photograph birds flying to and from the islands in the morning and evening. Adjacent to the bank of the lake is the museum - a must visit place. In future, the museum may be relocated in a more spacious modern building in New Town, though. Polonnaruwa is still a city unaffected by the plague of vehicular traffic as do many other cities in Sri Lanka. Enjoy driving /riding in this picturesque city before it is too late!

The ruins of Shiva Devales and Hindu style decors show the blend of the influence of Hindu culture on Sinhala Buddhist culture. In the complex of Gal Viharaya, there are imposing Buddha sculptures in granite. This is one of the most evocative pieces of sculpture in the world. A unique style of brick work architecture is also seen at Lankathilake Viharaya. The other interesting places are the ruins of the King's Council Chamber, the Royal Pavilion, Kiri Vehera and Gal Viharaya. All these places show the high standards of stone craft and artistry of this era. There are 658 villages in the district under seven local government authorities. From the sixth century A.D. onwards Polonnaruwa became increasingly expansion, important  and demographic  in the area is indicated by the construction of shrine rooms, an alternative residence for the Anuradhapura kings and hospitals at Polonnaruwa during the reigns of Silakala (518-31), Aggabodi-III (629- 39),Aggabodhi-IV (667-83) and Udaya-I (793-801) The South Indian Chola empire which conquered the northern part of Sri Lanka in 1017 A.D. established its capital in Polonnaruwa for 53 years until 1070 A.D. After the Cholas were expelled, the Sinhala kings too selected Polonnaruwa as their capital and it flourished for nearly two centuries until 1215 A. D. Iain, London

Lot to see. Those old ruins, castles, stupas and specially the beautifully carved Lord Buddha Statue. We all should take our children to visit these places and teach our history  so that they can appreciate the values values of those.

Ruins of the aniient capital, a world heritage site. Really interesting. There are magnificent statues of Buddha carved into the living rock.  The reclining Buddha is about 40 feet long. Whatever you do do not take a photo of yourself with your back to the Buddha. It is not allowed and we saw several people being yelled at because they were not showing respect.

This whole area is another World Heritage Site, and extensive needing transport to see it all. spent half a day here looking at all the ruins and enjoyed it very much. Our tour guide met up with his mentor who taught him his history of the site to pass on to us.

As per my own schedule, this visit was done on a rainy day. I had a private driver and upon arrival at the building where one is supposed to buy a ticket, the entrance is crowded with people trying to seek shelter from the rain. The parking area has no proper pathment so prepare to dirty your shoes since it's wet and sandy. Got myself an official guide which cost 3000lkr for 2 hours and I deeply regretted it. Acres of beautiful old buildings and Temples and Palace make up what used to be the second oldest kingdom in Sri Lanka. This really is a must see. You could spend an entire day here. Dress for very hot weather. Temple sites have a no shoe policy.
The council chamber of the king of the second oldest kingdom in Sri Lanka. Some beautiful carved rock  and stone make up what remains of what must have been an amazing building.
Beautiful ancient ruins, simply stunning and well preserved, definitely worth a visit, close to Sigria Rock, both can be seen in a day.
We were staying at a distance but much of fascination to be seen so glad we made the trip. Allow a couple of hours minimum but easy to spend all day there.

Polonnaruwa is the 2nd capital of Sri Lanka. History of Polonnaruwa dates back to 11th C. AD. Owing to ever increasing invasions from south India, the Sinhalese Kings nurtured by the non-aggressive policies of the Buddhism vacated Polonnaruwa and moved away from Dravidian invaders to south-west of the country.

Fascinating place to visit and see the history of this area. The remaining buildings have been preserved/rebuilt and give a great indication of the civilisation that existed here. But the most impressive part are the carvings in the rock and must not be missed.

We arrived at about 10.30am and the ticket office was rammed. A guide talked us into using his services (we had a driver already) and this proved to be a fabulous last minute decision. One of the ancient capitals of Sri Lanka the site is made up of three main parts, the museum, city ruins and the carved rock. The services of a good guide will greatly enhance the visit experience. Be aware that in parts of Polonnaruwa shoes will need to be removed and respectful dress is required ie no knees or shoulders on show.

We hired a bike and cycled around the ruins on a fantastic Sunday afternoon. Some fascinating sites and some busier than others but just hire a bike and give yourself 4 hours to enjoy the sites, make sure you take your camera! It‚Äôs also worth checking out the museum but do this after seeing the ruins, it‚Äôs quieter and you can get a greater appreciation of what must have been an unbelievable city.
This was an interesting visit to see a site that had remained ‚Äòlost‚Äô in the forest for many years. Well worth thevtrip.
This ancient city covers a large area and you need a car or a bike to get around. Highlight are the large stone carvings of the Buddha in the rocks

It was very interesting to learn about the ancient culture that created these monuments. We hired a guide which was $15 I think and we had a private driver for the duration of our trip so we drove in between monuments. Highly recommended!

What an interesting place! I mean, it‚Äôs vast and we were fortunate to have our driver who ferried us between sights and our guide taking us to the best bits. It covers a huge area, you could explore for a couple of days. So interesting to see all the ruins, especially the huge Buddha statues. Just remember to remove shoes and hafs, cover shoulders and not turn your back to the Buddha statues! Take socks if you‚Äôre going in the heat of the day - ouch!

Polonnaruwa is one of the best ancient cities I have been to. It is amazing to see how they built all the Sthupas, buildings, statues.... etc. thank to those who try to protect and maintain the ancient city.

The site is big. You will need to hire a car/tuk tuk/bike to go around. Be ready to spend at least a couple of hours there.  The ruins are amazingly, on par with those in Petra and Machu Picchu. Make sure you wear sandals as you will need to take off your shoes a lot to go into the sites and walk on dirt road.

We stayed in Pol in order to see the Archaeological ruins. On our arrival day we walked round the small site  directly beside Ekho Lake side hotel where we are staying, this appears to be free of charge and was a useful introduction. The next day we bought a ticket from the main ticket centre/Museum and hired a guide. Hiring a Guide 'on-the-street' as it were is always a gamble, the first person who latched on to me appeared to speak OK English, but after asking him a few questions it was apparent that his English was not really much good. The second person who approached me claimed to have been an english language teacher and was much better - but far from perfect. I'm not sure that a guide  you pick up on the street is really worth the hassle. Ours was quite useful in the Museum, but his interest waned during the next few hours and having made enough money from me  was keen to get back to his family for the rest of Poya Day. I thought we had agreed a price, his reccollection was slightly different ( take a piece of paper, write down the agreed price and each kepe a copy!) and when it came to tips, it was OK, then he suggested I also give him something for his lunch, then he spotted that my wife had ¬£'s in her purse and so suggested  ¬£10 towards his air fares fund! So altogether cost about double what I thought we  had agreed - but at the end of the day wasnt really much in European Terms. You would probably be better off with a good guide book and research printed off before you went. The sites are fairly spread out and the entrance is about 2-3Km's from the ticket office. So you need transport (we already had a van and driver for this part of our trip), I guess that visiting all the central sites and then back to the Museum was about 5-10kms, so it's not surprising that the further you travel the less busy the sites become - and actually they are the best parts, Tivanka Image House in particular. Some hire cycles to go round the sites - I would not reccomend it in 30+ degrees unless you are very fit. I would like to have spent more time there but  3-4 hours seemed to be the expectation of the guide and our driver. If I had wanted to visit for even 30 minutes the next day it would have cost another $50 for two of us. Having been to the Angkor Wat archaeological sites the previous year, there is no comparison, Angkor is much larger, much busier, much more interesting but also more expensive, but you can buy 3-day non consecutive tickets.

Our guide was very knowledgeable and answered all our questions, explained the history of the ancient site. Its a large area to cover with many interesting buildings.The sacred sites were  beautifully preserved. A must see site on a visit to Sri Lanka.

Polonnaruwa is the dilapidated fossils of an old fortress with ruins of palace, residential structures, pillars and alike in a vast area of greenery. It is worth visiting to have a peed into the pages of history.

all ruins now through the years of wear and tear. can still vaguely see the base structure the palace, it was a huge site with historical temples in place, definitely will need someone who knows the history of the place to explain, otherwise most likely you are only looking at stones and ruins which one would not understand. the site has been ruthlessly plundered and destroyed by the invaders.
You will need transport to see all parts of the site and it will take you approximately three hours to see it all. Lots of history and a guide will help. There are lots of ruins to see.

Interesting to explore and take in the culture. Not at all crowd and everything was very accessible. we were lucky enough to be escorted by our Guide who proved to be very informative. Various ruins do have visitor information boards in English. We were lucky enough to be accompanied by a huge Monitor Lizard roaming the grounds. A fascinating distraction from the ruins!
All this area is really interesting, learning about the history of Buddism and how the kings built their palaces. Learning all about cultures was well worth visiting this historical site.

It is impossible to see all the archeological ruins on foot.  You can either hire a driver, rent a tuk tuk, or borrow a bicycle (not recommended unless you are in good shape). Some of the sites require that the visitor remove their shoes and be dressed appropriately. Do a little bit of research before your visit.

We went here as a must if you visit Sri Lanka, the citadel is very big and you can still see a lot of details in the architecture. Take a big bottle of water with you! The only thing is that no all the people protect and respect the place, for example, all tourists wanted to take "the picture" but they gave their back to Buddha (you should not do that for respect) or they didn't notice somebody else was taking a picture. Please if you go to another country and visit we must be respectful of everything around us.
Yes ruins, but plenty to see and undesrstand. Guide was knowledgeable and made the visit come alive.

Some great ruins accompanied by te whole story of the royal palace and parliament style building. well worth a visit, get a guide if you can for better perspective and details. fascinating place, shame it was damaged in the civil war

Polonnaruwa is the second most ancient kingdom in Sri Lanka. It' s a must visit if you are interested in learning history and see the things related to ancient kings era of Sri Lanka.This place is a UNESCO world heritage site.

Unlike Anuradhapura where the ancient sites are dotted around the town, Polonnaruwa is contained in a fenced area several kilometres long. Further reviews of the different structures themselves are listed separately.

Polonnaruwa is amazing! My husband and I spent more then 4 hours walking around the ruins of this ancient city. WEAR CLOTHES THAT COVER YOUR KNEES AND SHOULDERS, particularly ladies. They will not let you in to see the temples otherwise.

Polonnaruwa is a well maintained and well enough run ancient city/archaeological site in the cultural triangle. Its very easy to get around via tuk tuk (and fairly inexpensive too) or you can go the bike route if you don't mind the heat. There are a number of sites to see but it can all be done in about three hours if you have a tuk tuk. Visitors should be prepared for crowds of people, many of whom will ignore well placed and easy to read signs about taking off shoes and not climbing on crumbling walls. There will be people in all of your pictures as well. Ultimately I have two different recommendations re: whether to visit: (1) If you have never seen a similar site I would recommend going - you will be interested the whole way through. (2) If you have been to  multiple other sites as I have, including in Cambodia, throughout Thailand and Burma this is ok to skip. I grew bored pretty quickly and didn't see anything new/different that made it worth a special trip. If you are in the area with an afternoon to kill (as I was) there are way worse ways to spend your time but be prepared to be underwhelmed.

We generally enjoyed what we saw here but we found that the support provided fo tourists is very poor. We were only provided a very basic map and were then largely left to the mercy of all the local touts, tuk tuk drivers, etc. After several 'bum steers' we eventually worked out what to do and where to go and saw some quite interesting ruins. Information provided at the ruins is generally very limited - our LP travel guide helped us to plug a few information gaps. Overall we felt that the site management is not really well tuned into the needs of tourists and is missing out on optimising the site's tourism potential.

As a family we walked around the entire site during an afternoon, not bothering with bike hire or tuktuk, it is flat so shaded by lots of trees.  We did hire a guide who was with us for 3 hours and cost 3000 rupee - we thought it worth it.  Get your tickets at the museum first.

Worth to see. Just note, that one object from another is far from each other, so at least rent a bicycle (app 3 eur per bike), so you can easily see all ruins. We noticed people were going by cars or busses, not sure how many costs this.

The world heritage ruins at Polonnaruwa appear to be on the list of every tour that passes through Sri Lanka's cultural triangle.  We were staying locally so could get a head start on most of the tours before they poured in.  Most people seem to cycle around the ruins and I could see why this would be attractive - it's cheap, easy and safe, and you can move between the different sites fairly quickly.  However, we were advised by a local to head to the top of the site by tuktuk then walk back to town, and I'd highly recommend this approach too - you'll get to see a lot more wildlife when you're walking, and trust me there's a lot to see if you keep your eyes open!  Saying that, you'll probably be fairly tired by the end, and make sure you take plenty of water.  The ruins comprise of a number of main sites interspersed by smaller, less-visited sites.  Be prepared for crowds at the main sites, with far fewer tourists at the smaller ones.  All are worth a visit though.  OK, this is not Angkor or Bagan, so don't expect it to be - I've been to both those and still reckon this is worth a visit if you're up in the cultural triangle.  However, I wouldn't bother staying in Polonnaruwa, I'd probably stay somewhere else - such as Dambulla - and get a tuktuk across for the day.

Having visited several similar sites in India, Cambodia etc. We found this site disappointing, but if this is your first ancient city site then you will enjoy it and then maybe visit Hampi, SiamReep, etc.

If this is the first Buddhist archaeological site you've ever visited, I'm sure it will be fine. Well maintained grounds, decent infrastructure for bike and tuk-tuk tours, and surprisingly good signage in English for this type of site. ...but if you've done any of the other Theravada Buddhist sites in Asia, this will leave you wanting more. Having done Bagan, Angkor, and Ayutthaya, I found Polonnaruwa downright boring. Granted, I'm jaded at this point, but I can't recall anything at this site that I hadn't seen elsewhere--other than the big temple that is positively *vibrating* with a bat colony in its hollows. The site also has that Angkor-esque picture taking issue, where the entire grounds tends to be distilled down to only a few scenic venues when people are showing off this place in pictures. I.e. if you're thinking of going based on a well-balanced shot of a seated Buddha surrounded by broken columns, be aware that you're not going to enter a site replete with similar ruins: you're seeing a picture of the only kneeling Buddha at Polonnaruwa surround by broken columns, and any pictures you get are going to exactly resemble the postcard that pulled you to Polonnaruwa in the first place, leaving one to wonder exactly how unique an experience it actually it to visit Polonnaruwa at all.

Once an ancient capital of Sri Lanka, Polonnaruwa is a must-see on any visit to this beautiful island.  The site itself is vast, with lots of ruins of ancient stupas, temples, water gardens, monk's lodgings, moats, etc  dotted around. it must have looked somewhat like Angkor Wat in its heyday. It is also hauntingly beautiful now, and although one of the more popular tourist sites, never seems crowded because of its vast size.  Towards the end of the site are exceptional and magnificent representations of the Buddha carved in stone - standing, seated and laying down. Definitely not to be missed!... For me however, the most intriguing building of all at this ancient site is a very odd and out- of- place (i.e.not buddhist nor hindu ) temple that has puzzled even eminent archaeologists which bears remarkable similarity to the architecture of the pyramids of the ancient Maya.  How can that be possible?......  A real mystery!

I expected more. The area doesn¬¥t seem to be that large and I definitely didn¬¥t find it as ‚Äûa lost city in the jungle‚Äú. Main attractions were full of visitors and souvenir sellers. On the other hand I also have to admit that my disappointment arose from Polonnaruwa city itself which is very dusty, noisy and hard to find good local restaurants here. We rented bikes just in front of the entrance for 500 LKR/pc (they didn¬¥t want to lower their price at all). Got flat tire twice which was embarassing.
We had a guided tour around the multiple sites that was informative and interesting. Well worth a visit.

We took a tuk tuk here to take us from one area to the next, he waited between each place dropping us right by the entrance paths, it was well worth it as the area is quite large and the ruins clustered together.  Bikes were available to hire as well. Beautiful ruins, with lots of details quite different from Anurashapura. It was not a hectic here and you felt you had more time to absorb the atmosphere of the place

I visited here with a your group and we hired bikes to get between each of the ruins. This was a great experience and was much better than the lengthy walk would have been! That said check your bike over before you leave the rental area. My first bike had a flat tire so I wouldn't have got too far, so I was glad to have spotted when I did. Wear loose clothes as it was hot work under the sun. There is lots to see and plenty of history to keen most people interested. It does get busy with tour groups and if cycling be careful on the roads as buses don't think twice about bikes!

This a very vast archeological site with many nice ruines.If you do not want to drve by car, you can rent a bike near the entrance and take your bicycle from the start to the end, a very nice way to travel and be able to go to some more remote sites, with less people around.
Magnificent! Past signs situated into a wonderful landscape. Our guide (from Sri Lanka) was kindly And very clever. Beautiful day between past And nature!

Went for a morning stroll along the ruins. It was a pretty nice expierence. Because I went quite early it was not so crowed.but you could see the bulk of the people come in by the time I moved out of the ruins. I is worth getting up early for this one.

Many beautiful ruins, recommend using a guide though- our driver came with us and gave so many interesting facts and explanations about the ruins, carvings, history etc. (Some buildings are so destroyed, makes it easier to understand what you're looking at). We hired bicycles for 500Rs each, fun and easy to get around, don't have to worry about locking bikes in the complex. Be very careful not to take photos with your back to the Buddha statues, they are very strict! Recommend having a quick walk through the museum where you buy your tickets, gives a good overview of what you're a out to see.
we spent one day in Polannaruwa. great ancient buildings Sthupas, Stone carved statues. the Watadage And Hatadage also significant engineeringstractures...

Even though Polonaruwa is amongst the most visited places, the vastness of the coplete area disperses the masses to an extent that it is possible to feel nearly alone sometimes. We liked it very much.

Pricey entrance fee but I thought it was still worth it (US$25).  Be sure to cover your shoulders and knees.  Lots of dogs too, not that they bother you. Absolutely loved the ruins of this ancient city - from the monks quarters and medical block to the temple and royal palace, the stone carving is spectacular. Wandering around soaking up the atmosphere was spiritually invigorating.

The ancient city of polonaruwa was facinating. It had many ancient stone buildings that you could walk around and many temples to go in. My tips for visiting Polonaruwa is to bring a scarf of garment to cover your bare legs as in certain areas and temples it is mandatory to cover bare legs a matter of respect.

Vast and overwhelming, this ancient site is best visited with an experienced guide who will give you enough information to appreciate it before blowing your mind with too many details. That is ....unless, you're an archeological geek who could spend weeks exploring this site. Many stupas and remnants of communities abound, and one detail you can trace is the elaborate water system throughout. There is a reason that the entire area is now part of UNESCO's World Heritage sites.

Terrific for a day, only an enthusiast would need longer. I had pre-arranged a scooty rental with the same company doing cycle near the entrance. The strategy I used, which worked well, was to do the north then head south towards the main entrance. We'd missed out Polonnaruwa on previous visits to Sri Lanka because most tours don't include it in their itineraries.  I am so glad we made the effort this time.  The museum was excellent and set the scene well for our leisurely tour around the ruins.  Everything is so well kept and well organised - we bought an English guide book and our driver helped fill in the important historical background.  The park is lush and green and in many areas the jungle was just waiting to reclaim the ruins - makes for great photos!. But it was also wonderful to visit somewhere so culturally important without hordes of other tourists.  Highly recommended.  Remember that because of the number of temples visitors have to be dressed respectfully so take a sarong with you.
We started our tour from museum and ended it from Gal viharaya. Walking is not possible as the ruins are well away from each other. Cycling possible. There are plenty of cycle hire places.

As luck would have it our driver asked someone who turned out to be an official guide (not a scam) and told us we could drive around in our van between the main sites and walk from the car parks. Which we did and it was the best thing...also the guide was excellent (Sunil...he was involved in the restoration of the site and now does guiding in his retirement). We spent about 4 hours visiting the various sites with our guide giving very good explanations (his knowledge was vast...get him talking about the technical details of the restoration). He was also excellent at getting his timings right to avoid crowds (peak holiday season for locals). On his recommendation we visited the sites first and then as the heat really ramped up we headed into the AC cooled museum where we were wowed by the pre-restoration photos and the models of key buildings. Definitely the best order to visit and the way to travel around in the heat!

Towards the beginning of the 12th century AD, Polonnaruwa became the second capital of the Sinhalese. Little is left nowadays from the old capital and visiting the Archeological Park would give you an idea of the beauty and the size of the place. One can easily spend half a day just walking around, looking at the different ruins and wondering how the city must have looked like back then...

In our opinion and alongside the marvelous Dambulla caves and the Sigiriya Rock Fortress/Palace, the ruins of Pollonaruwa Archeological Park are one of the most interesting remains of the island's glorious past and one of the main reasons for us coming to Sri Lanka. I really like the ruins in Polonnaruwa. It takes a about 4 hours to explore all the park and it‚Äôs best to go by bike. It was alright but not as astonishing as expected. Good for a one-day trip, either on foot or by bike.

My recommendation is to u to visit the ruins at night. The place is well lit and it‚Äôs not too crowded too. It‚Äôs better u choose a full moon day so u can take stunning photographs. One of the best places I‚Äôve visited. üòçüòç

Polonnaruwa is an interesting place, it was the capital of the island in the middle ages during several centurys. The most impresive are the four sculptures of buda. The visit, in a big area, is very well indicated and apropiated for moving by yourself. Rent a vehicle, bike or scooter is the good option.

Spread over a vast expanse this archaeological park holds many wonders of a time that‚Äôs lost in history. Not a whole lot of known about these ruins but what it has left behind are some stunning stupas and temples housing Buddha. We chose to walk and drive around instead of renting a bicycle and cycling around the ruins. I would visit again just to immerse in the space surrounded by lush green space.

We went to see the ancient city of polonnaruwa. Inside the ancient city there are many and most places to see. You can go in vehicle to see most sites. Remember to wear long clothes covering your knees. Plus it will get really warm so take your sunscreen, hats and water. Also there are shops where u could buy everything. For tourists there is a price to pay for entry. Its wonderful to see these ruins as you tend to think how beautigul and magnificent it must have been back in the day!

It‚Äôs a large site and well worth a visit although it‚Äôs $25 each and they DON‚ÄôT take cards - cash only. Lots of walking or take a bike. Demure dress code - clothing below knees and covered shoulders. No selfies allowed!!!! Honestly. Quite ‚Äúruined‚Äù but some interesting remnants and statues. Lots of history. The highlight is the four varying size Buddha‚Äôs carved side by side  out of the same granite rock face (one is about 17m long, another 7m tall). You start in the museum which gives you some perspective of the overall site and how it might have been 1000 years ago. Moving between the ruins you can imagine how the place functioned as capital and get some idea of how the people lived their lives. The four Buddha carvings in the rock are simply fantastic.

The ancient city is def worth a trip. Very very warm. Wear loose fitting clothes that cover your shoulders. Beware of the monkeys thet are easily irritated & gave my husband a stern warning by hissing at him. I would advise renting bikes it makes travelling between each ruin easier. We came across a cobra snake charmer, it just added to the atmpsphere of the area. The local sellers gently encourage you to buy postcards etc. We did not find them too aggressive. Its a great day & I would recommend a visit!

The Archaeological Ruins date back to the time when the Capital of Sri Lankan kingdom was located there in Polonnaruwa, few centuries ago. Though the structures are in ruined state, they are still impressive and indicate their glorious past. The area of the ruins are well maintained with proper passages and greenery all around. We had hired a Tuk Tuk on the Main Road, from where the side road leads to the Ticket counter and driver, Mahinda, acted as our guide. He was quiet informative and entertaining.

Second Capital of Sri Lanka was known to be located in Polonnaruwa. The remnants of the erstwhile Capital are currently existing in ruined state. Most of the ruins are located in relatively close proximity, however, a visiting all of them on foot may not be easy. The place is worth a visit and provides great opportunity for photography enthusiasts. There is ample greenery around the sites, which is quite soothing to the senses.

a beautiful and very impressive cultural site which you should visit either with enough pre-praparation or a guide as there is tons of important and valuable information ... go to the museum first and then visit the sites ... ENJOY!

As I was staying in Dambulla, I had to take a bus to visit Polonnaruwa‚Äôs sights. From the main street of Dambulla, there are regular buses heading towards Kaduruwela ‚Äì which is an adjacent part of Polonnaruwa where the train and bus stations are located. Hopping onto any bus that is heading to Kaduruwela will get you into Polonnaruwa. However, it is best to tell the bus conductor to drop you off in the ‚ÄúOld Town‚Äù, which is (I think) the first main drop-off as you enter Polonnaruwa (from the direction of Dambulla). The bus journey took about 90 ‚Äì 100 minutes, and cost 100 rupees. After getting off the bus in the Old Town, ask around to get to the Museum -- just short walk away along a canal -- where you can buy a combined ticket for the museum and the archaeological sights. It cost 3975 rupees but is valid only for one day. The museum gives a so-so introduction to the history of the Sri Lankan kingdoms, putting the ruins of Polonnaruwa into a larger context. Curation has room for improvement. Moreover, the airconditioning was weak and it was warm and humid inside the place. The ticket comes with a pretty useless map. The staff know that the map is useless. So the lady advised me to take a photo of the wall-mounted map which gives clearer directions of where the ruins are situated. What's so difficult about designing and printing a new map? The fact that no one has yet done so gives you a clue about shoddy management standards. From the museum‚Äôs exit, walk northwest through a small garden to the group of ruins on the shore of the lake known as Parakramabahu Samudera. Then walk east and cross the main road, to the entrance to the other section of the ruins. Your ticket will be checked again. The ruins are in three main clusters: the lakeshore cluster (also known as the ‚Äòisland‚Äô group), the royal palace cluster and the quadrangle cluster, each about 500m from each other. But there are plenty more sites scattered a few kilometres around. Some ruins are in bad shape; the ones in the sacred quadrangle are perhaps in the best condition. It wasn‚Äôt possible to cover much more than the three main clusters in the time (a daytrip) that I had. Based on my experience, I‚Äôd say that if you want to examine most of the ruins, I think you will need a much earlier start, which means staying in Polonnaruwa the night before and the night after. I am rating his site as merely "average". Even allowing for the fact that ruins that are 800 - 1100 years old can't possibly be in good condition, when I compare it with other archaeological sites of similar vintage around the world, Polonnaruwa is not outstanding. The stone construction does not look to have been built to a high standard; the sculpture works were relatively few and not particularly good aesthetically. The fundamental reason, I suppose, is that the kingdom over which Polonnaruwa controlled was probably a smallish one (by world standards) and it might never have had the resources to build a truly great capital city. As a second-class city, today we have second-class ruins. Add to that sub-par management, lack of cafes and toilets in the sites despite the heat and great distances... and my feeling at the end of the day was a degree of dissatisfaction.

We stayed at Sigiri and travelled out each day to Polonnurawa and Anuradhaphura. Polonnurawa is certainly worth a visit. There is really a lot of history here. We came with a tour guide so we got the low down on the history. Again expect to pay for the admission which is around 3500 LKR ( pls check before going ) each.  This is about the same price as for Anuradhaphura . The majority of the  entrance fees go towards maintaining the site and further excavations, so you are funding a good cause.  After paying for the admission do go round the museum which is where you get the admission tickets.   The visit to the museum is worthwhile especially if you don‚Äôt have a guide. It explains each monument and the history behind it.  And also the history as to why the Kings moved from   Anuradhaphura to Polonnurawa to start a second kingdom. Polonnurawa  started in the 10th Century as the capital city  and ended around the 12th Century . Apparently it had lain undiscovered until British archeologists began probing in the late 19th century when the whole area was covered in forests.  When you look at the buildings do look at the surrounding trees. Their bases are about 1.5 m to 2 m above the ground of the excavations. It will have taken some serious excavations to get to the monuments. Some places are just spectacular.  The Royal palace for one, the second is the lake or a ‚Äòtank‚Äô as they call it.  This huge lake of 25 sq km was manually excavated in the 12th century by people and elephants.  It really is quite an awesome task. There are some temples which are in ruins and previously held the Scared Relic of the Tooth ( now housed in Kandy).  Just do note that the dress code applies to temple ruins as to living temples. No shorts, or crop tops and no slippers on the temple grounds ( even abandoned ones).  A few visitors were caught out and not allowed in. Having visited both Polonnurawa and Anuradhaphura I think if you don‚Äôt have enough time then Polonnurawa is the better choice.  But if you have the time and inclination then do visit both places .

Anuradhapura was the capital of ancient Ceylon from about 455BC that was ruled from by successive kings until 1017 when the Cholas from South India captured King Mihindu V, and destroyed much of Anuradhapura and established their own capital at Polonnaruwa. The Cholas lasted until 1070 when the Sinhalese King Vijayabahu drove them out of the island. Vijayabahu retained Polonnaruwa as his capital as did successive kings until the late 13th century. But Polonnaruwa proved difficult to defend against invaders from India and the Sinhalese kingdom moved across to the west coast and Polonnaruwa was allowed to decay. By the late 13th century Ceylon had 2 ancient abandoned capitals although, as ruins, there is still much to see. Anuradhapura is the more extensive and the more important as a religious site for Buddhist pilgrims, whereas Polonnaruwa, the more recent, is in better condition and compact, is considered more important for its archaeology, art, architecture, engineering and agriculture. The ruins of Polonnaruwa are very impressive, demonstrating a remarkable standard of scale, design and construction and, in particular, the detail. There are more than 30 significant buildings and statues here, mostly enclosed within the ancient walls and overlooking the enormous hand dug 2,500 ha Parakrama Samudraya tank as directed by King Parakramabahu I. There are also irrigation tanks and waterways that supplied the gardens and fields. It is believed that King Parakramabahu fully understood the importance of irrigation and is said to have declared that ‚Äònot even a drop of water that comes from the rain must flow into the ocean, without being made useful to man‚Äô. On the site is the ticket counter, information centre, small museum, air conditioned auditorium and a small bookshop. But it is the ruined buildings and statues that visitors come to see and a good way to explore those is by hired bicycle. However the vast site is so complex that to best understand it, you would need a guide. Our little party had our own transport and recruited an official guide to show us the sights and provide an informative running commentary. There are both official guides (those with badges) and un-official ones. Our guide was well informed and we felt the cost of R 3,000 was justified. You would need at least 3 hours to cover the entire site including walking around the ruins and taking those essential tourist photographs.
