Went here as part of our trip to Sri Lanka and fortunately had an excellent guide with us as this really helped when visiting this site.   The museum was an interesting start followed by a trip around the whole site.  It was truly amazing place and our guide information and explanation brought the place alive.  Clearly one has to dress appropriately and remove one's shoes in places but this shows respect and therefore is clearly not an issue.   A worthwhile place to visit and very well maintained.

The many ruins are spread over a large area so our coach took us from site to site.  The moonstones and guardstones were in an excellent condition.  I stood in quiet contemplation in front of the large stone Buddhas at our last stop.  Very impressive.

I was a bit sceptical to start with visiting Polonnuruwa ruins after previously been to Siem Reap (Angkor Wat) 2 yrs ago. I didnt really know what to expect probably due to my own ignorance but upon visiting with my wife & 2 young kids (8&10), I was very impressed. There are plenty of well retained ruins steeped in history. Its a really interesting bit of history. The ruins are over a large area, you can cycle around or get a guide & transport or if you have a driver use your vehicle. It would be hard to walk around due to the heat. My two daughters struggled a bit with the heat but in their defence they climbed Lion Rock earlier in the morning. I highly recommend visiting the museum to gain a little knowledge before browsing the ruins. Highly recommend visiting this site whilst in the Cultural Triangle.

Best advice is to use a bicycle to visit the area. The place is big but easy with bike and there are plenty for rent around. If you're travelling in a small group my best advice would be to do it ahead of the buses that are all going the same place at the same time. Be smart and observe first where they're going. Then you could be almost alone on the various sites. Half a day is definitely not too much for it and the beauty and peacefuness of the site is really amazing.

We visited this site in early February on a fairly warm day i.e. temperature about 23 degrees. We had guide with us. The advantage of a guide is that they can help you make the most of your visit by selecting out what to see and more importantly they have the knowledge of what is inter-connected and in close proximity too. This is massive heritage site and you cannot explore all of it in one day so selecting out points of interest and finding them is a challenge. Best to read up about it before you arrive as that may help you select out what you think suits you best. Alternatively just meander and explore. There is an option to hire cycles and that could be a good way to explore the site. Whether walking or cycling or with a driver guide you will almost certainly come across structures which will amaze you. The architecture is a delight if you have not previously seen buddhist or hindu heritage sites before. One of the joys was seeing carved granite carvings in the structures which convey stories. Hindu architecture is very different from Buddhist architecture. One revers the Buddha without much reference to the animal kingdom and the other is prolific in carving animals, 'grotesque' masks and moonstones with story telling symbolisms threaded throughout the buildings and statues. One is also relatively simplistic in design while the  other is over complicated, yet they are in harmony too. So this a site where you can marvel at the size and shapes of early structures, whether they be structures like a giant wedding cake or stupa's which are round and dome like. Another joy of visiting this place is the sense of freedom you have to explore it. However there is an obligation that visitors show extra respect for those sites with a special religious significance. This presents no problems if your address is appropriate i.e. no knees (men and women) showing and the female head is covered. However this applies only to certain special places here not all of them. This is also a site that has grass and avenues of trees to contrast with the massive  brick structures. Until I visited this place I never realised that bricks were being made in the 12 century and were being used to build multi storey buildings and places of worship. If you are not keen on heritage ruins and history you will probable not rate these sites very much. For me it was interesting, enjoyable, varied and wonderful because of it heritage. I have not previously seen a nothing quite like it on this scale despite travelling to over 20 countries.
the ruins are in 3 or 4 separate blocks. definitely hire a bike. a guide would be nice to unstandardised intricacies.

hiring a cycle was interesting and probably a must and quite inexpensive. entrance fees are a little steep. you visit an old large city. English signs help in understanding some history though in retrospect a guide would have been a better option. we missed the highlight.. the sleeping buddha. there are options of coconut water and ice lollies and water everywhere. do wear a large hat as the sun even in February was scorching. its about an hours drive from sigriya

It‚Äôs a big site, on a par with Angkor Wat and loads to see. Really give yourself a day to slowly go round this enormous range of monuments. Also wear SOCKSas in hot weather barefoot on the stones is painfully hot

Must see in Sri Lanka if you wanna taste the breeze of ancient times. You will feel like in the middle of the jungle, surrounded by monkeys, deer, lizards and flocks of various species of birds. The site is huge and the best way to see it is from a bike. On our way from Dambulla, we just hopped off the bus and there was the guy, lending bikes for 800 Rupies right on the side of the main road. It took us approx. 3 hours to see the whole place and we would have spent there much more time if we were not in hurry.

This is a must do on any trip up into the cultural quarter of Sri Lanka.  This is a UNESO World Heritage site which in its hey day was in the 11th/12th century and was one of the most important cities in Sri Lanka.Overall it is not bad shape! There is so much to see that you should plan on spending 1/2 a day here. You can walk it but it could be quite exhausting and extremely hot and there are no shops for water etc. Hire a bike or better still an A/C car. You should hire a guide as they have a wealth of knowledge  and it will avoid you missing out on stuff. I suggest that you start in the museum (next to where you pay), the head  south to Potugal Hihara, then do the Royal Palace Complex, then the Quadrangle and then work you way up the site to Gal Vihara (the star of the whole show) then head a tad further north to the "Lotus Pond" and finally the Tivanka-Patamaghara ( a hidden gem). Doing the Complex properly makes a great day!

This is a great place to visit in the area and pretty much a must-see. We opted for this rather than anaradhapura as it was nearer, smaller, more compact and better-preserved. You start at the ticket office, which has a museum behind it telling you the history of the site and the temples. It's worthwhile hiring bicycles to get around the temples (they can be got from just outside the site) to speed things up a bit and zip around - inside the site itself the roads are very quiet though you will have a stretch on a fairly busy (and currently under repair) road. You can also get a tuk tuk around it. The royal palace group, quadrangle group and northern group are the main ones you'll visit. There is the "island" group and others further south, but we were hugry and had seen the best-preserved ones by that point and opted not to bother. The ruins are well-preserved and beautifully maintained. You'll have to do a fair bit of taking shoes on and off, and make sure your shoulders and knees are covered as some of the areas are holy and it's a mark of respect. These areas are clearly signposted. All in all it's a great day out.

We where guided trough most of the area and is was so large, but also interesting about the history. It was almost too much in the short time we where here so we got a bit exhausted. But wouldn't liked to missed it. The problem was our tour guide tried to squeeze to hurry up due to the bad wheater it was really poring and he didn't like the rain so much. It would have been nice to take the time we needed but we where on a schedule unfortunatley. Nice area but I recommend you plan to spend at least 3 hours here to be able to take everything in. Museum was not that interesting.

This was a huge area to visit and we were lucky to have a car and chauffeur to move us around and to explain a bit about the ruined temples. Some areas were difficult to walk about on and there was some confusion about where one should take off ones shoes. Sometimes the rough rocky surface deterred shoe removal anyway. A bit of information of the exhibits would have been useful but it left one with an overall impression of past greatness.

This is a truly impressive site with many buildings which have been rebuilt as far as possible.  When found the site was covered in jungle and over many years has been reconstructed.  Certain artefacts are in the museum, where there are scale models of the original buildings.  Visit this either before or after you visit the site to get a true perspective on what the site was like originally.  A guide is recommended to avoid missing the most important buildings and temples.  Socks are recommended on hot days, if you want to visit the temples!

You could easily spend all day here- i'd be hiring a bike next time. We had a whistle stop tour courtesy of our guide Sampath Maragoda- superb guide from our travel company Diethelm Tours. The site is very extensive and worth spending some time exploring

Probably the best historic site of whole Sri Lanka,and ,by far, most popular. It is pretty crowded but it cant spoil the beautiful ruins of this ancient city. We hired a tuk tuk and it took us almost 3 h to go through the whole thing. Highly recommended

This is an important UNESCO world heritage site and has been extensively rebuilt.  It is best visited with a guide.  We spent a couple of hours here, but it would have been easy spend longer.  There are several temples, where shoes have to be removed to enter - a bit of a problem on very hot days, so socks are recommended.  The buildings are quite spaced out so a car is useful.  Tickets are obtainable from the museum further down the main road.

We would highly recommend Polonnarawu (people staying at our guest house who visited both Polonnarawu and Anaradhapura found the latter disappointing in comparison).  Entry is not cheap -  25$ per person ‚Äì but it is an impressive site, with well-preserved monuments and good landscaping.  It is a generally peaceful site, with a prevailing air of calm and respect.  The one exception was the completely inappropriate loud music blaring from the refreshments area half way round.  We spent around four hours there which enabled us to visit all the temples and monuments.  We spent a further 30 mins in the museum adjoining the ticket office. Practicalities: Polonnarawu covers a large area, so walking the whole site, which covers a large area, might be a challenge - particularly in the 30 degrees heat.  We had hired a driver for the day so he came with us into the site (entry is free for locals) and dropped us off at each of the main areas to wander around at leisure ‚Äì the car a/c in between stops was very welcome!  Another option is to hire a bike outside the site, which a number of people did ( depending on where you hire bikes from the downside is that you may have to cycle for a stretch on the main road ‚Äì contending with all the usual crazy Sri Lankan traffic- either at the start of the tour or end).   Socks are recommended when entering the temples as it can be very hot underfoot.  About half way round there are toilets ‚Äì those for foreigners were clean & in a reasonably good condition.  There were also the aforementioned refreshment stalls.   There are similar facilities (albeit less clean toilets) just before the exit.

This is a World Heritage site and a must if you are in the area.  The place is large, but it is easy to walk the ground to the various sights that are all open to the public.  In some one must remove shoes.  I would suggest that one reads up about this site in advance since there is a lot to absorb.  Also you would be well prepared to ask questions to your guide as you go from one to another.
